consent:
The only requirement for participation in this study is that you are an adult (18 years or older).



Purpose:

The purpose of this research study is to test interview techniques for use when questioning criminal suspects or intelligence sources.



Procedures:

If you volunteer to participate in this research study, we will ask you to do the following:

You will be asked to take part in several activities in the laboratory facility (e.g., accessing computers, collecting items). After these activities, you will be interviewed. You may be asked to lie during this interview. After the interview, you will be asked to complete questionnaires about your experiences in the study.

The interview will be audio recorded. You will be given an opportunity to listen to this recording, and you will be given the opportunity to delete the file. If you withdraw from the study, we will delete your recording. All recordings will be stored in a locked data storage room or password protected hard drive. Only members of the research team will have access to the recordings. Recordings will be used only for research purposes (e.g., data coding).

We cannot tell you every detail of this study ahead of time, but if you are willing to participate under these conditions we will explain the procedures to you fully after your participation.




Time Commitment:

Your participation in this research study is expected to last for 60 minutes for the first lab session. The following two sessions are expected to last 30 minutes.



Potential Risks or Discomforts:

Participants may experience some stress during the interview.



Potential Benefits:

You will not directly benefit from your participation in this research study.



This study may provide valuable information about how police and military personnel can question suspects in an effective manner.



Payment for Participation:

You will be paid 150 SEK for each lab session (total 450 SEK). You will be paid the whole sum after you have completed your participation.



Confidentiality:

We will make our best efforts to maintain confidentiality of any information that is collected during this research study. We will disclose this information only with your permission or as required by law.



We will protect your confidentiality by ensuring that your name and other identifying information is not be present on any of the questionnaires for this study. All documents and recordings will be stored in a locked data storage room or on a password protected hard drive (for electronic files).



The research team, authorized University staff and government agencies that oversee this type of research may have access to research data and records in order to monitor the research. Research records provided to authorized, non-University individuals will not contain identifiable information about you. Publications and/or presentations that result from this study will not identify you by name.



Participants’ Rights:

Your participation in this research study is entirely voluntary. If you decide not to participate, there will be no penalty to you, and you will not lose any benefits to which you are otherwise entitled.



You can decide to withdraw your consent and stop participating in the research at any time, without any penalty.



Contact:

Lina Nyström

PhD Candidate

lina.nystrom@psy.gu.se

Also, I claimed that as a master's student I did not have access to the area she was accusing me of being. I still insisted on the absurdity of the accusations and continued to support my alibi of studying with classmates before my arrest.

So i tried to tell them as much as i could, while still trying to not give away my true intentions and my crimes.

strategy_free: I did not think that I could convince the interviewer that I was innocent, but I had a strategy for not implicating myself. I have heard that individuals involved in organized crime in Sweden have a strategy of not saying anything at all in police interviews, in order to be able to come up with the (to themselves) most beneficial testimony after information has been presented to the court by police investigators and other suspects. If I would commit a crime I therefor think that the safest strategy in an interview would be to not say anything at all. I also think that the risk of me providing information to the police that could be used against me is greater than the chance that anything I say could be beneficial to me.

kind of. i tried to make up a story where most of the details were correct so that i could quickly answer in case the interviewer asked questions about my story(she didn't though). i said i came here to look for my friend who goes to this school because his friends and i havent heard from him in a few days and his friends in jönköping where he is doing his internship at the moment said he had gone to gothenburg for something school-related. the friend is real and he does go to this school and is doing an internship in jönköping but he is not missing. i also claimed to only remember details that i believe i would have remembered if i were actually here looking for my friend.

If I remember things right, when I read the cognitive psychology course I learned that what makes peoples stories of true memories different from made up stories is that the stories of true memories is much more detailed. I therefor had as a strategy to say nothing that was untrue since a made up stories could be identified as such because of its lack of detail. When I got questions about my activities that might implicated me in the crime, I stated that I do not remember. At the same time I saw no reason of not answering questions when I believed the answer to them would not implicate me in the crime. When I got a question of my activities that I believed could not implicate me in the crime, I described my memory in detail. I also made sure not the describe the places I went to to commit the crime in greater detail than other areas of the building, since I thought this might implicate me.

As I in this scenario have "committed" the crime, I know that whatever I say could be used against me. I also believe that the goal of a police interview where I already am considered as a suspect to have committed a crime is to find out more information and hints about my potential involvement in that crime. Therefore, I chose to say "no comment" to not have the officer gather more material about me that could lead to a judgement.
change_strategy_free: It was quite easy to keep this strategy as I decided for it beforehand. I could imagine that some try to convince the interviewer that they are innocent by taking a friendly and open approach but then realise that they might get trapped into giving out more information. I did not want to take that risk.

strategy_free: My strategy was to simply reply that I do not know or do not remember when I was asked questions that might implicate me in the crime. When I was asked questions that I believe would not implicate me in the crime, or for which I had real memories from that day unrelated to the crime, I told the interviewer as much as I could.

Same as last time. I believe that if I give any information to the interviewer, they will just find things that can be used against me. So If they already suspect me it is best to say no comment for not making my case "worse".

My strategy, such as it is, means giving legitimate reasons for being where I was and sticking to my story as much as possible. Appointment with a professor on the fourth floor relating to my stutter, a mental break to clear my head on the patio on the third floor and trying to find the restroom before leaving.

I tried to remind myself what I said the last time and recreate it the best and the most similarly I could. I tried not to say or add too many details or new information to the story so I would not get lost in my confession or confuse myself.

I worked from the idea that I had legitimate business during "the incident", where I had an appointment in room 427 regarding my stutter and that my movements on the day was me going to and from that appointment, with a mental break on the patio on the third floor, etc.

Just like the previous times I tried to avoid too many details and I tried to stick to my initial story as best as I could. When the interviewer was asking if I touched anything I tried to give kinda vague answers, like "It is possible but I do not think so" or that I do not recollect because I thought it would be weird and suspicious if I remembered my every move.
